wiki_catalogs.name: System Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the intelligent-stock-prediction system. Explain its purpose as a full-stack application combining ML-based stock prediction with sentiment analysis and portfolio management. Describe the core goals: enabling simulated trading, providing predictive analytics, and supporting investment decision-making. Identify the target audience (students, researchers, amateur investors) and explain how the system bridges gaps in isolated prediction tools by integrating end-to-end workflows. Cover the high-level architecture (three-tier: presentation, application, data), key components (Flask backend, SQLite, LSTM/ARIMA models, sentiment analysis), and user roles (regular users, administrators). Include practical examples from the README such as default admin credentials and common user workflows. Document integration points like Alpha Vantage and yfinance, and highlight unique features such as commission tracking and dividend recording. Address common setup issues and performance considerations for local deployment.

wiki_catalogs.name: System Architecture Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the intelligent-stock-prediction system's high-level structure. Describe the three-tier architecture: presentation layer (Jinja2 templates and static assets), application layer (Flask routes and business logic), and data layer (SQLAlchemy models and SQLite database). Explain system boundaries and external entities including Users, Admins, and Market Data APIs. Document data flows using DFD Level 0 diagram: user interactions, authentication flow, prediction engine inputs/outputs, sentiment analysis pipeline, and admin monitoring pathways. Illustrate component interactions between frontend templates, Flask controllers, ML models, and database models. Address technology choices and trade-offs such as using SQLite for development simplicity versus production scalability limitations. Include deployment topology considerations and infrastructure requirements for local versus cloud deployment.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Authentication System sub-feature. Thoroughly explain implementation details including user registration, login/logout workflows, password hashing with security best practices, CSRF protection, and role-based access control (RBAC) for user and admin roles. Document how authentication integrates with session management in Flask and protects sensitive routes. Include concrete examples from main.py showing route decorators and security middleware. Explain relationships with the User model and database persistence. Address common issues such as failed logins, password reset considerations, and session expiration. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers regarding Flask-Security patterns and secure credential handling.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the User model. Detail all fields: id (primary key), email (unique, not null), username (unique, not null), password_hash (not null), role (not null, default 'user'), wallet_balance (not null, default 0), created_at (default current timestamp), last_login_at, and is_active (default true). Explain the security implications of password hashing using Werkzeug's generate_password_hash. Document the role-based access control system with 'user' and 'admin' roles. Describe the relationship with PortfolioItem (one-to-many), Transaction (one-to-many), and Dividend (via PortfolioItem). Include business rules such as unique email/username constraints, wallet balance management during transactions, and account activation status. Provide examples of querying user portfolio holdings and transaction history. Document indexing on email and username fields for authentication performance.

wiki_catalogs.name: Authentication API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for authentication endpoints in the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Document the /register (POST), /login (POST), and /logout (GET) endpoints with their HTTP methods, URL patterns, request parameters (email, username, password, confirm_password for registration; email and password for login), and response behaviors (redirects, flash messages, session management). Include authentication requirements and CSRF protection mechanisms. Explain how these endpoints integrate with the User model and session management system. Provide examples of request/response flows from test_web_routes.py test cases. Address security considerations including password hashing, CSRF token validation, and session clearing on logout. Include client implementation guidelines for form submissions and error handling.

wiki_catalogs.name: User Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the User model. Detail all attributes including id, email, username, password_hash, role, wallet_balance, created_at, last_login_at, and is_active with their data types and constraints. Explain the check_password method implementation and password hashing using Flask's security utilities. Document the relationship between User and other models (PortfolioItem, Transaction, Dividend). Use test_database_models.py to illustrate validation rules, uniqueness constraints on email and username, and default values. Include code examples showing user creation, authentication flow, and session management. Address security considerations like password hashing, role-based access, and account activation status. Explain how wallet_balance is used in trading operations and maintained across transactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Prediction Pipeline
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details, invocation relationship, interfaces, domain model and usage patterns. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase. Document configuration options, parameters, and return values. Explain relationships with other components. Address common issues and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers. Focus on the end-to-end prediction workflow from user input to forecast visualization. Detail the sequence: stock symbol input → historical data retrieval via yfinance → data preprocessing (handling MultiIndex, CSV export) → execution of ARIMA, LSTM, and Linear Regression models → aggregation of predictions and RMSE values → sentiment analysis integration → final recommendation generation (BUY/SELL/HOLD). Explain how the pipeline handles fallbacks (e.g., Alpha Vantage when yfinance fails) and error conditions. Use test_prediction_pipeline.py to illustrate expected behavior, mocking strategies, and edge case handling. Document the creation of visualization assets (Trends.png, ARIMA.png, LSTM.png) and their role in the UI. Include performance considerations for model execution and caching opportunities.

wiki_catalogs.name: LSTM Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the LSTM model implementation. Explain the architecture of the 4-layer LSTM network with 50 units each, dropout layers (0.1), and Dense output layer. Document the data preprocessing pipeline: 80/20 train-test split, MinMaxScaler normalization (0,1), and creation of 7-day timesteps for sequence modeling. Describe the model compilation using Adam optimizer and mean squared error loss. Detail the training process with 25 epochs and batch size 32. Explain prediction workflow including inverse scaling to restore original price values and RMSE calculation. Cover forecasting mechanism using the last trained sequence to predict the next day's closing price. Include integration with the Flask route in main.py where LSTM predictions are visualized in 'static/LSTM.png' and returned with actual values for D3 visualization. Address common issues like overfitting, vanishing gradients, and long training times. Provide optimization tips for GPU acceleration, batch size tuning, and early stopping. Use examples from test_lstm_model.py showing mock models, data shaping, and RMSE validation.

wiki_catalogs.name: yfinance Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the yfinance integration in the intelligent-stock-prediction system. Document how yfinance is used for retrieving historical stock price data, including the specific parameters and date ranges used in data retrieval. Explain the implementation details of the get_historical function in main.py, including error handling when data is empty and the fallback mechanism to Alpha Vantage. Detail the data transformation process, including handling of MultiIndex columns and CSV export. Include code examples showing how yfinance data is integrated into the prediction pipeline for ARIMA, LSTM, and Linear Regression models. Explain the relationship between yfinance data and other components like the prediction engine and data visualization. Address common issues such as API rate limits, data formatting changes, and network timeouts, providing troubleshooting guidance for each. Include performance considerations for large datasets and optimization tips for data retrieval and processing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Finviz Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Finviz integration sub-feature. Explain how the system scrapes financial news headlines from Finviz using HTTP requests and BeautifulSoup parsing. Document the implementation of the get_finviz_news method in ComprehensiveSentimentAnalyzer, including handling of the news-table element, URL extraction, and title parsing. Include code examples showing the use of proper User-Agent headers to avoid 403 errors and the fallback mechanism when full article text cannot be retrieved. Describe how publish dates are extracted from Finviz data and how this information is incorporated into sentiment analysis. Address challenges such as rate limiting, HTML structure changes, and error handling during scraping. Provide guidance on troubleshooting common issues with Finviz integration and optimizing performance through caching strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: High-Frequency Trading (HFT)
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the High-Frequency Trading use case configuration. Explain how the system is optimized for sub-5-minute latency requirements with aggressive caching and minimal article processing (10 articles). Document the configuration that prioritizes the fastest available sources, specifically Finviz with FinVADER sentiment analysis as the primary source. Describe the intended integration with Webz.io (not currently implemented) for real-time data streams and Redis for caching to achieve 55k articles/sec processing throughput. Include code examples from the demo showing initialization of the ComprehensiveSentimentAnalyzer with HFT configuration and expected performance metrics. Provide guidance on deployment patterns for low-latency trading systems and how this configuration enables generating trading signals 3-5 minutes before price movements.

wiki_catalogs.name: EODHD API Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the EODHD API integration sub-feature. Document the implementation of the get_eodhd_sentiment method, including the API endpoint URL pattern, authentication via API token, and response structure handling. Explain how the sentiment data is retrieved in JSON format and how the associated news articles are fetched separately to enrich sentiment scores with full content. Detail the error handling mechanism for network failures and invalid responses, and describe how missing API keys result in graceful fallback. Include code examples showing the two-step process of fetching sentiment data and corresponding news articles. Address configuration requirements for the EODHD_API_KEY environment variable and discuss performance benefits of using pre-calculated sentiment scores compared to local analysis. Highlight use cases where this source is preferred, such as high-frequency trading scenarios requiring low-latency data access.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the technology stack of the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Break down the stack into Backend (Python, Flask, SQLAlchemy, SQLite), Machine Learning & Analytics (TensorFlow/Keras, Scikit-learn, Statsmodels, NLTK, TextBlob, FinVADER, yfinance, Alpha Vantage), and Frontend (HTML5/CSS3, Bootstrap, JavaScript, D3.js, jQuery). For each technology, explain its role in the system, version compatibility, and configuration requirements. Detail external API dependencies including authentication mechanisms and rate limits. Provide practical examples from requirements.txt showing package versions and groupings (e.g., ML vs web). Document integration patterns between components (e.g., how Flask routes serve ML predictions). Address common dependency conflicts, installation pitfalls, and virtual environment setup. Include performance implications of key libraries like TensorFlow and strategies for optimizing ML inference speed.

wiki_catalogs.name: Design Patterns & Implementation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content on key design patterns implemented in the codebase. Explain the MVC pattern with Flask routes as controllers, Jinja2 templates as views, and SQLAlchemy models as the data layer. Document the dependency injection pattern used for API key management across external services. Describe the fallback mechanism pattern in sentiment analysis, where multiple sources (Finviz, EODHD, Google News) are prioritized with failover logic. Detail the use case configuration pattern that enables different sentiment analysis profiles (HFT, retail, academic). Provide code examples from main.py and news_sentiment.py demonstrating these patterns. Explain the rationale behind each pattern choice, integration points, and how they improve system resilience and flexibility. Address common issues like API rate limiting and source unavailability, and how these patterns mitigate such problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Prediction Engine
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Prediction Engine sub-feature. Explain the implementation of LSTM, ARIMA, and Linear Regression models for stock price forecasting within the Flask application. Document data preprocessing steps, model training pipelines, hyperparameter configurations, and prediction execution workflows. Include examples from main.py showing how yfinance data is fed into each model and how predictions are formatted for frontend display. Describe ensemble methods if used and model accuracy evaluation. Explain relationships between the prediction engine and sentiment analysis inputs. Address common issues like overfitting, model convergence, and performance bottlenecks. Provide optimization tips for faster inference and memory efficiency. Include usage patterns for triggering predictions via web interface or API.

wiki_catalogs.name: Company Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Company model. Detail all fields: id (primary key), symbol (unique, not null), name, exchange, sector, and is_active (default true). Explain the purpose of each field in the context of stock prediction and portfolio management. Document the relationships with PortfolioItem (one-to-many), Transaction (one-to-many), and Dividend (one-to-many). Describe business rules such as symbol uniqueness, active status for trading eligibility, and metadata enrichment during company creation. Include examples of querying companies by symbol for prediction requests and filtering active companies for trading operations. Document indexing on symbol field for fast lookups during trading operations and prediction workflows.

wiki_catalogs.name: Prediction API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for the stock prediction endpoint in the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Document the /predict (POST) endpoint with its HTTP method, URL pattern, and request parameter (nm - stock symbol). Detail the response behavior including template rendering and prediction generation through ARIMA, LSTM, and Linear Regression models. Explain the integration with news_sentiment.py for sentiment analysis and yfinance for historical data retrieval. Include information about the prediction workflow, data processing, and visualization outputs (Trends.png, ARIMA.png, LSTM.png). Provide examples from test_web_routes.py showing test cases for the prediction route. Address error handling for invalid symbols and data retrieval failures. Include client implementation guidelines for form submission and response interpretation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Company Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Company model. Detail attributes including id, symbol, name, exchange, sector, and is_active with their data types and constraints. Explain the unique constraint on stock symbol and its role as a primary identifier for financial instruments. Document the relationship between Company and PortfolioItem/Transaction models. Include code examples showing company creation through admin interface, symbol validation, and usage in stock prediction workflows. Address how company metadata (exchange, sector) supports portfolio analysis and reporting. Explain the is_active flag's role in controlling which stocks are available for trading. Use test_database_models.py to illustrate proper instantiation and validation rules.

wiki_catalogs.name: Trading Operations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details, invocation relationship, interfaces, domain model and usage patterns. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase. Document configuration options, parameters, and return values. Explain relationships with other components. Address common issues and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers. Focus on the trading logic for buy/sell operations in the simulated environment. Detail the request flow: CSRF verification → user authentication → symbol validation → quantity parsing → current price retrieval via yfinance → wallet balance and commission validation → database transaction atomicity. Explain the calculation of average buy price during partial purchases and portfolio cost basis updates. Document the role of the active broker in commission calculation and transaction logging. Include the state changes to PortfolioItem, Transaction, and User wallet_balance. Address edge cases like insufficient funds, invalid quantities, and non-existent symbols. Use test_trading_operations.py to illustrate test coverage for success and failure scenarios. Explain the simulation nature of trades and implications for real-world deployment.

wiki_catalogs.name: ARIMA Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the ARIMA model implementation. Explain the ARIMA(6,1,0) configuration: 6 autoregressive terms, 1 differencing for stationarity, and 0 moving average components. Document the time series preprocessing: date parsing with '%Y-%m-%d' format, handling missing values via backfill, and 80/20 train-test split. Describe the rolling forecast origin approach where the model is retrained iteratively as new observations are added to history. Detail the prediction workflow including RMSE evaluation and visualization in 'static/ARIMA.png'. Explain how forecasted values are extracted from the last two predictions for next-day closing price estimation. Include integration with the Flask application where ARIMA results are stored for D3 visualization. Address common issues like non-stationary data, insufficient history for model order, and constant price series. Provide guidance on parameter tuning (p,d,q), seasonal decomposition, and performance considerations for recursive forecasting. Use examples from test_arima_model.py showing model fitting, forecast validation, and edge case handling.

wiki_catalogs.name: Alpha Vantage API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Alpha Vantage API integration in the intelligent-stock-prediction system. Document the dual use of Alpha Vantage for both financial data retrieval (as a fallback when yfinance fails) and news sentiment analysis. For financial data, explain the implementation of the TimeSeries API calls with API key authentication, including the specific endpoints used (daily adjusted data) and parameters (output format, output size). For sentiment analysis, detail the News & Sentiments API integration, including query construction, response parsing, and the composite scoring algorithm that combines headline and content sentiment. Explain the fallback pattern implementation where Alpha Vantage serves as a secondary source when primary sources fail. Include code examples showing API key configuration, request patterns, and error handling strategies. Address rate limits, authentication requirements, and data transformation logic. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like invalid API keys, rate limiting, and response format changes. Include performance considerations for API calls and caching strategies to minimize redundant requests.

wiki_catalogs.name: Alternative News Sources
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the alternative news sources sub-feature. Cover the integration of multiple API-based sentiment sources including EODHD API, Alpha Vantage News & Sentiments API, Tradestie WallStreetBets API, Finnhub Social Sentiment API, and StockGeist.ai. Document the implementation details of each source's dedicated method (get_eodhd_sentiment, get_alpha_vantage_news, etc.), including API endpoint URLs, authentication mechanisms, response parsing, and error handling. Explain how sentiment scores are normalized across different sources and how metadata like publication dates are preserved. Include code examples showing asynchronous requests for StockGeist streaming and batch processing for social sentiment data. Address challenges such as API rate limits, authentication key management, and handling inconsistent response formats. Provide guidance on configuring API keys and selecting appropriate sources based on use case requirements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Retail Trading Apps
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Retail Trading Apps use case configuration. Explain how the system is optimized for cost-effectiveness with zero-cost APIs and 15-minute latency tolerance. Document the configuration that uses Tradestie Reddit API and Finviz with FinVADER sentiment analysis, processing only 5 articles to minimize API usage. Describe how this configuration enables real-time WallStreetBets sentiment integration in mobile applications. Include code examples from the demo showing initialization of the sentiment analyzer for retail applications and the expected user impact. Provide guidance on implementing this configuration in consumer-facing trading apps and how it balances performance with budget constraints.

wiki_catalogs.name: Alpha Vantage News & Sentiments API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Alpha Vantage News & Sentiments API integration. Cover both implementation paths: using the newsapi client library when available and falling back to direct HTTP requests to the Alpha Vantage endpoint. Document the request construction for the NEWS_SENTIMENT function, including ticker parameters and API key authentication. Explain how the response is parsed from the 'feed' array and how publication timestamps are extracted. Detail the hybrid sentiment scoring approach that combines headline and content analysis using FinVADER with weighted averaging (60% headline, 40% content). Include code examples demonstrating both the library-based and direct request approaches. Address error handling for import failures, network issues, and malformed responses. Discuss configuration requirements and optimal use cases such as quantitative hedge funds that benefit from premium sentiment data with high accuracy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Installation & Setup
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on installing and setting up the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Provide step-by-step instructions starting from repository cloning to running the application, using exact commands from the README. Detail prerequisites (Python 3.7+, pip), virtual environment creation, and dependency installation via requirements.txt. Explain configuration requirements including API key setup using the API_KEYS_GUIDE.md, environment variables, and service authentication for Alpha Vantage and other data providers. Document database initialization procedures and schema migration steps. Include troubleshooting guidance for common issues (port conflicts, missing dependencies, API key errors). Provide verification steps to confirm successful installation, such as accessing the local server and logging in with default credentials. Add tips for development vs production setups and debugging initialization problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Flow Diagrams
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for all data flow diagrams in the system. For DFD Level 0, explain the five main processes (Authentication, Portfolio Management, Prediction Engine, Sentiment Analysis, Admin Monitoring) and their interactions with external entities and data stores. For DFD Portfolio Level 1, break down the Portfolio Management process into its subprocesses: Place Buy Order, Place Sell Order, Record Dividend, and View Portfolio & Wallet, detailing data flows and storage interactions. For the Use Case Diagram, document actor-system interactions distinguishing between User and Admin capabilities. Map each diagram element to actual code components (e.g., P2.1 to buy_stock function in main.py). Include mermaid.js code blocks for visualization and explain how these diagrams guide system understanding and development. Provide interpretation guidance for developers using these diagrams to troubleshoot or extend functionality.

wiki_catalogs.name: Sentiment Analysis
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Sentiment Analysis sub-feature. Cover the integration of Finviz scraping with FinVADER for financial sentiment scoring, alternative news sources (Alpha Vantage, EODHD API), and fallback mechanisms when primary sources fail. Document the selectable sentiment source architecture that supports different use cases (HFT, retail, academic). Explain the text preprocessing pipeline, sentiment scoring logic, and aggregation methods. Include code examples from news_sentiment.py showing asynchronous requests and error handling. Describe how sentiment scores are normalized and fed into the prediction engine. Address challenges like rate limiting, HTML parsing with htmldate, and sentiment bias across sources. Provide guidance on configuring source priorities and adding new sentiment providers.

wiki_catalogs.name: PortfolioItem Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the PortfolioItem model. Detail all fields: id (primary key), user_id (foreign key to User, not null), company_id (foreign key to Company, not null), quantity (not null, default 0), average_buy_price (not null, default 0), and created_at (default current timestamp). Explain the cost basis calculation methodology where average_buy_price is updated on additional purchases. Document the bidirectional relationships with User (many-to-one) and Company (many-to-one). Describe business rules such as preventing negative quantities, maintaining accurate cost basis during partial sales, and cascade deletion when user/company is removed. Include examples of calculating unrealized gains/losses by comparing average_buy_price with current market price. Document indexing on user_id and company_id for efficient portfolio queries.

wiki_catalogs.name: Portfolio Management API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for portfolio management endpoints in the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Document the /dashboard (GET), /trade/buy (POST), and /trade/sell (POST) endpoints with their HTTP methods, URL patterns, and request parameters (symbol, quantity). Explain the integration with the PortfolioItem, Transaction, and Company models, including business logic for calculating commissions, updating wallet balances, and maintaining average buy prices. Include information about authentication requirements and CSRF protection. Provide examples from test_web_routes.py showing test cases for trading operations. Address error handling for insufficient funds, insufficient shares, and invalid quantities. Include client implementation guidelines for executing trades and monitoring portfolio performance.

wiki_catalogs.name: PortfolioItem Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the PortfolioItem model. Detail attributes including id, user_id, company_id, quantity, average_buy_price, and total_invested with their data types and constraints. Explain the composite nature of this model as the core of portfolio tracking, maintaining current holdings per user per stock. Document the relationships with User, Company, and Dividend models. Include code examples showing portfolio item creation during stock purchases, quantity updates on subsequent buys/sells, and deletion when quantity reaches zero. Address business logic like average cost basis calculation, total investment tracking, and integration with dividend recording. Use test_portfolio_management.py to illustrate proper state transitions and edge cases.

wiki_catalogs.name: Portfolio Valuation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details, invocation relationship, interfaces, domain model and usage patterns. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase. Document configuration options, parameters, and return values. Explain relationships with other components. Address common issues and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers. Focus on the algorithms used to calculate portfolio performance metrics. Detail the dashboard logic: aggregation of PortfolioItems → calculation of total invested (quantity × average_buy_price) → retrieval of current market prices via yfinance → calculation of total current value → determination of profit/loss. Explain the use of Decimal for financial calculations to avoid floating-point errors. Document the integration with the trading operations and dividend recording features. Address performance considerations for portfolios with many holdings and strategies for caching price data. Use test_portfolio_management.py to illustrate test cases for valuation accuracy under various market conditions and portfolio compositions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Linear Regression Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Linear Regression model implementation. Explain the feature engineering process: creating the 'Close after n days' target variable with 7-day shift, and preparing feature matrix X from closing prices. Document the data preprocessing pipeline: 80/20 train-test split, StandardScaler normalization for zero mean and unit variance, and preparation of forecast data from the last 7 days. Describe the model training using scikit-learn's LinearRegression with n_jobs=-1 for parallel processing. Detail the 7-day forecast generation, application of 1.04 adjustment factor, and mean calculation for final prediction. Explain RMSE computation and visualization in 'static/LR.png'. Cover integration with the Flask application where predictions and actual values are formatted for D3 visualization. Address common issues like linear assumptions in non-linear markets, overfitting on small datasets, and sensitivity to outliers. Provide optimization tips including feature selection, regularization techniques, and ensemble usage with other models. Use examples from test_linear_regression_model.py showing data preparation, scaling, and accuracy validation.

wiki_catalogs.name: EODHD API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the EODHD API integration in the sentiment analysis system. Document how EODHD API serves as a primary fallback for sentiment data with pre-calculated sentiment scores. Explain the implementation details of the get_eodhd_sentiment method, including API endpoint structure (sentiments and news endpoints), query parameters, and authentication via API token. Detail the data transformation process that combines sentiment scores with news content and metadata. Explain the error handling strategy for network timeouts and API failures, including the 10-second timeout configuration. Include code examples showing the API request pattern, response parsing, and integration with the fallback mechanism. Address the relationship between EODHD API and other sentiment sources in the priority chain. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as invalid API keys, rate limiting, and malformed responses. Include performance considerations for API response times and optimization tips for efficient data retrieval.

wiki_catalogs.name: Selectable Configurations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the selectable configurations sub-feature. Explain the architecture that allows users to choose specific sentiment sources based on their needs, using the SentimentSource enum and selected_sources parameter. Document how the _should_use_source method determines which sources to activate during sentiment analysis. Describe the configuration options for enabling all sources or specific combinations, and how this affects the analysis workflow. Include code examples showing different configuration scenarios and their impact on performance and accuracy. Address use cases where selective source configuration improves efficiency, such as disabling social media sources for traditional financial analysis. Provide guidance on best practices for source selection based on data freshness requirements, cost considerations, and target audience.

wiki_catalogs.name: Quant Hedge Funds
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Quant Hedge Funds use case configuration. Explain how the system is optimized for accuracy with premium data sources and hybrid scoring techniques. Document the configuration that uses Alpha Vantage Premium API and Finviz with FinVADER sentiment analysis, processing 20 articles with a 60/40 headline/content scoring composite. Describe how this configuration supports backtesting with historical data and achieves LLM-quality sentiment scoring. Include code examples from the demo showing initialization with Alpha Vantage API key and the expected backtested alpha of 8-12% annually on mid-cap stocks. Provide guidance on implementing hybrid scoring and leveraging premium APIs for institutional-grade trading strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Finnhub Social Sentiment API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Finnhub Social Sentiment API integration. Document the implementation of the get_finnhub_social_sentiment method, including the API endpoint URL construction with symbol and authentication token. Explain how the response contains social sentiment data from multiple platforms (Reddit, Twitter) and how the code processes these sources separately. Detail the application of FinVADER to raw social media text and the volume-weighted sentiment scoring that multiplies sentiment by mention count. Describe the data transformation process that converts social mentions into standardized news items with platform-specific titles and URLs. Include code examples showing the iteration over platforms and individual mentions. Address error handling for API connectivity issues and response parsing failures. Discuss configuration requirements for the Finnhub API key and highlight use cases where social sentiment monitoring is critical, such as retail trading applications tracking community sentiment.

wiki_catalogs.name: Architecture & Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create architectural documentation for the intelligent-stock-prediction system. Describe the three-tier architecture (presentation, application, data layers) and MVC pattern implementation using Flask routes (controllers), Jinja2 templates (views), and SQLAlchemy models (models). Document key architectural patterns: dependency injection for API keys, fallback mechanisms in sentiment analysis, and use case-based configurations. Explain system boundaries, component interactions, and data flows using DFD Level 0 and Level 1 diagrams. Detail design trade-offs such as using SQLite for simplicity versus scalability limitations. Include infrastructure requirements, deployment topology options, and scalability considerations. Address cross-cutting concerns: security (authentication, CSRF), monitoring (error handling dashboard), and disaster recovery (data persistence). Reference use case diagrams to illustrate user-system interactions and component breakdowns.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Interactions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Document the integration and interaction between major system components. Explain how the Flask application in main.py orchestrates the prediction workflow: receiving user input, retrieving market data via yfinance, processing sentiment through news_sentiment.py, and combining results for display. Detail the interaction between authentication system and protected routes, including session management and role-based access control. Describe how portfolio management components interact with database models during trading operations. Explain the integration between sentiment analysis module and prediction engine, including data format and error handling. Provide sequence diagrams in mermaid.js format showing critical workflows like stock prediction request and trade execution. Include code examples demonstrating component coupling and dependency management. Address performance implications and optimization opportunities in component communication.

wiki_catalogs.name: Portfolio Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Portfolio Management sub-feature. Explain the virtual wallet system, stock buy/sell operations, commission calculations based on broker configurations, and dividend recording mechanics. Document how transactions update portfolio valuations in real time and how holdings are visualized on the dashboard. Include examples from main.py showing transaction processing logic and database updates. Describe the relationship between PortfolioItem, Transaction, Dividend, and Broker models. Address common issues like insufficient funds, fractional shares, and transaction rollback scenarios. Provide usage patterns for portfolio rebalancing and performance tracking. Include best practices for handling financial calculations with precision and audit logging.

wiki_catalogs.name: Transaction Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Transaction model. Detail all fields: id (primary key), user_id (foreign key to User, not null), company_id (foreign key to Company, not null), broker_id (foreign key to Broker), txn_type (not null, values: BUY/SELL/DIVIDEND), quantity (not null), price (not null), total_amount (not null), commission_amount (not null, default 0), created_at (default current timestamp), and description. Explain the transaction lifecycle for buy/sell operations including commission calculation based on active broker rates. Document the relationships with User (many-to-one), Company (many-to-one), and Broker (many-to-one). Describe business rules such as atomic updates to wallet balance during transactions, validation of sufficient funds for purchases, and proper handling of partial sales. Include examples of generating transaction history reports and calculating total trading volume by symbol. Document indexing on user_id, company_id, and created_at for performance optimization.

wiki_catalogs.name: Funds Management API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for funds management endpoints in the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Document the /funds/topup (POST) endpoint with its HTTP method, URL pattern, and request parameter (amount). Explain the integration with the User model for updating wallet_balance and the transaction recording in the Transaction model. Include information about authentication requirements, CSRF protection, and input validation for monetary amounts. Provide examples from test_web_routes.py showing test cases for the top-up route. Address error handling for invalid amounts and edge cases. Include client implementation guidelines for fund management operations and balance updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Transaction Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Transaction model. Detail attributes including id, user_id, company_id, broker_id, transaction_type (BUY/SELL), quantity, price_per_share, total_amount, commission, and created_at with their data types and constraints. Explain its role as an immutable ledger of all trading activities. Document relationships with User, Company, and Broker models. Include code examples showing transaction creation during buy/sell operations, commission calculation based on broker rates, and usage in generating trade history reports. Address business rules like transaction validation (sufficient funds for buys, sufficient shares for sells) and atomic updates to portfolio and wallet. Use test_trading_operations.py to illustrate proper recording of all transaction details and edge cases.

wiki_catalogs.name: Commission Calculations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details, invocation relationship, interfaces, domain model and usage patterns. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase. Document configuration options, parameters, and return values. Explain relationships with other components. Address common issues and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers. Focus on the commission calculation logic used in trading operations. Detail the calculate_commission function: input parameters (total_amount, broker object) → conversion to Decimal → percentage calculation using broker.commission_rate → quantization to two decimal places. Explain the role of the Broker model in storing commission rates and the selection of the active broker. Document the impact on both buy (deducted from wallet) and sell (deducted from proceeds) transactions. Address edge cases like missing brokers, invalid commission rates, and zero-commission scenarios. Use test_trading_operations.py to illustrate test coverage for different commission rates and transaction types. Emphasize the importance of precision in financial calculations and the use of Decimal arithmetic.

wiki_catalogs.name: Google News RSS
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the Google News RSS integration as a last-resort sentiment source. Document how Google News RSS provides fallback news coverage when all other sentiment sources fail. Explain the implementation details of the get_google_news method, including RSS feed URL construction with dynamic query parameters, XML parsing with BeautifulSoup, and item extraction logic. Detail the data enrichment process that adds publish dates using the htmldate library when available. Explain the role of this integration in the fallback hierarchy as the final option when higher-priority sources are unavailable. Include code examples showing the RSS request pattern, response parsing, and integration with the article text extraction system. Address reliability considerations such as RSS feed availability, rate limiting, and content quality. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like malformed XML, network timeouts, and missing content. Include performance considerations for RSS parsing and optimization tips for efficient feed processing.

wiki_catalogs.name: Fallback Mechanisms
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the fallback mechanisms sub-feature. Explain the priority-based fallback system implemented in the get_sentiment method, where the system progresses through sources from primary (Finviz) to secondary (EODHD API) to tertiary (Alpha Vantage) and finally to last resort (Google News RSS). Document how the system checks the number of articles collected at each step and only proceeds to the next source when the target number is not met. Include code examples showing the conditional logic that governs the fallback sequence and how errors in one source do not prevent subsequent sources from being attempted. Describe the role of the _should_use_source method in determining which fallback options are available. Address how the system handles partial failures and maintains data integrity when some sources are unavailable. Provide guidance on customizing the fallback sequence and configuring timeout values for optimal reliability.

wiki_catalogs.name: Academic Research
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Academic Research use case configuration. Explain how the system is optimized for historical depth and reproducible results with free data sources. Document the configuration that prioritizes Google News RSS and Finviz with FinVADER sentiment analysis, processing 50 articles to ensure comprehensive data coverage. Describe how this configuration enables long-term sentiment trend analysis and publication of research papers on social media's predictive power. Include code examples from the demo showing initialization for academic use with extensive article processing. Provide guidance on using this configuration for longitudinal studies and ensuring methodological rigor in financial research.

wiki_catalogs.name: Tradestie WallStreetBets API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Tradestie WallStreetBets API integration. Document the implementation details of fetching Reddit sentiment data from the public Tradestie API endpoint without authentication. Explain how the code processes the results array and filters mentions based on query relevance (ticker or text matching). Detail the application of FinVADER for refined sentiment analysis on raw Reddit comments, replacing the API's basic sentiment score with more nuanced financial sentiment scoring. Describe the data enrichment process that creates news items with Reddit-specific metadata including source labeling and comment-based titles. Include code examples showing the relevance filtering logic and sentiment refinement process. Address error handling for network failures and JSON parsing issues. Discuss the advantages of this source for capturing retail investor sentiment from communities like r/WallStreetBets and its suitability for fintech startups targeting retail traders.

wiki_catalogs.name: Database Schema Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the application's database schema. Detail all entities: User, Company, PortfolioItem, Transaction, Dividend, Broker. For each entity, define field types, constraints, primary/foreign keys, and relationships. Use the ER diagram to illustrate cardinality and associations (e.g., one User to many PortfolioItems). Explain business rules enforced through database constraints (e.g., transaction validation, portfolio balance checks). Include sample data representations and access patterns (e.g., querying user holdings). Document performance considerations like indexing strategies on frequently queried fields (user_id, company_id). Specify data lifecycle management, retention policies for transaction logs, and backup procedures. Address data security aspects including password hashing in the User model and access control implications.

wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Dashboard
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Admin Dashboard sub-feature. Describe the administrative interface for managing users, companies, brokers, and monitoring system-wide transactions. Document the role-based access control that restricts dashboard access to admin users only. Explain how real-time statistics and system health metrics are aggregated and displayed. Include examples from main.py showing admin-only routes and template logic from admin_dashboard.html. Describe use cases such as user suspension, broker commission updates, and audit trail inspection. Address security considerations for protecting admin endpoints and preventing privilege escalation. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common administrative tasks and performance monitoring of backend services.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dividend Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Dividend model. Detail all fields: id (primary key), portfolio_item_id (foreign key to PortfolioItem, not null), amount_per_share (not null), total_amount (not null), payable_date, and created_at (default current timestamp). Explain the dividend recording process where total_amount is calculated as amount_per_share multiplied by current holding quantity. Document the relationship with PortfolioItem (many-to-one) which maintains the link to user and company. Describe business rules such as preventing dividend recording for zero or negative holdings, automatic crediting of wallet balance upon dividend recording, and data integrity through foreign key constraints. Include examples of calculating dividend yield and generating dividend income reports. Document the cascade deletion behavior when a PortfolioItem is removed.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dividend Management API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for dividend management endpoints in the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Document the /dividends/record (POST) endpoint with its HTTP method, URL pattern, and request parameters (symbol, amount_per_share). Explain the integration with the Dividend, PortfolioItem, Transaction, and User models, including business logic for calculating total dividend amounts and updating wallet balances. Include information about authentication requirements, CSRF protection, and validation for holdings and dividend amounts. Provide examples from test_web_routes.py showing test cases for dividend recording. Address error handling for non-existent holdings and invalid dividend amounts. Include client implementation guidelines for recording dividend payouts and updating portfolio values.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dividend Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Dividend model. Detail attributes including id, portfolio_item_id, amount_per_share, total_amount, declaration_date, and created_at with their data types and constraints. Explain its role in tracking income from stock holdings. Document the relationship with PortfolioItem (via portfolio_item_id) and the calculated total_amount field. Include code examples showing dividend creation through admin interface, automatic calculation based on current holdings, and impact on portfolio valuation. Address business logic like dividend recording workflow, historical tracking, and reporting for tax purposes. Use test_portfolio_management.py to illustrate proper association with portfolio items and calculation of total dividend income.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dividend Recording
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section. Thoroughly explain implementation details, invocation relationship, interfaces, domain model and usage patterns. Include concrete examples from the actual codebase. Document configuration options, parameters, and return values. Explain relationships with other components. Address common issues and their solutions. Make content accessible to beginners while providing sufficient technical depth for experienced developers. Focus on the dividend processing workflow. Detail the record_dividend route: CSRF verification → user authentication → symbol and amount validation → portfolio ownership check → calculation of total dividend payout (amount_per_share × quantity) → creation of Dividend record → crediting of user's wallet_balance → creation of DIVIDEND transaction record. Explain the relationship between PortfolioItem and Dividend models. Document the simulation nature of dividend recording and its impact on portfolio valuation. Address edge cases like non-existent holdings, invalid amounts, and fractional shares. Use test_portfolio_management.py to illustrate test coverage for successful dividend recording and error conditions. Explain how this feature contributes to the overall investment simulation accuracy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Finviz Scraping
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the Finviz web scraping implementation as the primary news source. Document how Finviz provides fast and reliable financial news headlines through direct HTML scraping. Explain the implementation details of the get_finviz_news method, including URL construction, HTTP request configuration with custom User-Agent headers to prevent 403 errors, and BeautifulSoup parsing of the news-table element. Detail the data extraction process that captures headlines, links, and publication timestamps from table rows. Explain the integration with full article text extraction using the newspaper3k library. Include code examples showing the scraping workflow, error handling for network issues, and timeout configuration. Address the relationship between Finviz scraping and the FinVADER sentiment analysis system. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like blocked requests, parsing errors, and site structure changes. Include performance considerations for scraping efficiency and optimization tips for minimizing request overhead.

wiki_catalogs.name: Use Case Configurations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the use case configurations sub-feature. Explain how the system supports different financial analysis scenarios through the UseCase enum and _apply_use_case_config method. Document the five predefined use cases: HIGH_FREQUENCY_TRADING, RETAIL_TRADING_APPS, QUANT_HEDGE_FUNDS, ACADEMIC_RESEARCH, and FINTECH_STARTUPS. For each use case, detail the specific configuration parameters such as number of articles, selected sentiment sources, and performance optimizations. Include code examples showing how to initialize the ComprehensiveSentimentAnalyzer with different use cases and the resulting behavior changes. Describe how use case configurations optimize the system for specific requirements like low latency for HFT, cost-effectiveness for retail applications, or historical depth for academic research. Provide guidance on selecting the appropriate use case and extending the system with custom configurations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Fintech Startups
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Fintech Startups use case configuration. Explain how the system is optimized for rapid MVP development with real-time data streams and developer-friendly APIs. Document the configuration that uses StockGeist.ai and Finviz with FinVADER sentiment analysis, processing 15 articles with real-time streaming capabilities. Describe how this configuration provides 10k free monthly credits and FastAPI integration for quick deployment. Include code examples from the demo showing initialization for startup use cases and the expected go-to-market timeline of one week. Provide guidance on leveraging this configuration to launch sentiment-powered features quickly and scale as the user base grows.

wiki_catalogs.name: StockGeist.ai Real-Time Streaming
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the StockGeist.ai real-time streaming integration. Document the asynchronous implementation using aiohttp for handling Server-Sent Events (SSE) streams from the StockGeist API. Explain the endpoint URL construction for real-time sentiment streams and the authentication mechanism using Bearer tokens. Detail the event loop that processes incoming JSON messages and applies FinVADER sentiment analysis to each message's text content. Describe how the streaming nature enables real-time alerts and how the function handles message parsing errors gracefully. Include code examples showing the async context manager usage and message processing loop. Address configuration requirements for the StockGeist API key and discuss optimal deployment patterns for maintaining persistent connections. Highlight use cases in fintech startups requiring real-time market sentiment monitoring and how this source fits into low-latency trading systems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the core features of the intelligent-stock-prediction system. Provide an integrated overview of Authentication System, Prediction Engine, Sentiment Analysis, Portfolio Management, and Admin Dashboard functionalities. Explain how these features interact within user workflows (e.g., login → predict → trade → monitor). Document feature dependencies and data exchange patterns (e.g., sentiment scores influencing predictions). Include usage examples from actual user journeys and highlight key differentiators from similar systems. Address configuration requirements for each feature set and describe how they contribute to the overall value proposition. Use diagrams and template references to illustrate feature implementation and UI integration. Prepare to subdivide into detailed sub-features in the next level.

wiki_catalogs.name: Broker Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Broker model. Detail all fields: id (primary key), name (not null), email, commission_rate (not null, default 0), and is_active (default true). Explain the role of brokers in simulating realistic trading costs through commission calculations. Document the relationship with Transaction (one-to-many) where each transaction references the broker used. Describe business rules such as preventing negative commission rates, ensuring only one active broker is used for commission calculations, and maintaining broker configuration through the admin interface. Include examples of calculating commissions for buy/sell operations and retrieving the active broker for trading operations. Document the default commission rate of zero for simulation purposes and how it can be configured for more realistic scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Admin Management API
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for admin management endpoints in the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Document the /admin (GET), /admin/brokers (POST), and /admin/companies (POST) endpoints with their HTTP methods, URL patterns, and request parameters (broker: name, email, commission_rate; company: symbol, name, exchange, sector, is_active). Explain the role-based access control requiring admin privileges, integration with Broker and Company models, and data validation rules. Include information about authentication requirements, CSRF protection, and flash message feedback. Provide examples from test_web_routes.py showing test cases for admin functionality. Address error handling for invalid inputs and permission restrictions. Include client implementation guidelines for admin operations and system configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Broker Model
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the Broker model. Detail attributes including id, name, commission_rate, commission_fixed, is_active, and created_at with their data types and constraints. Explain its role in calculating trading costs and supporting multiple brokerage configurations. Document the relationship with the Transaction model and the application of commission rules during buy/sell operations. Include code examples showing broker creation through admin interface, commission calculation using both percentage and fixed components, and active broker selection for trading. Address business rules like ensuring only one active broker at a time and commission calculation edge cases. Use test_trading_operations.py to illustrate proper commission application and broker selection logic.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Endpoints Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create API documentation for all public endpoints in the intelligent-stock-prediction application. For each RESTful endpoint in main.py, document HTTP methods, URL patterns, request parameters, response schemas (including status codes), and authentication requirements. Categorize endpoints by functionality (authentication, prediction, portfolio, admin). Include examples of request/response payloads from actual test cases in test_web_routes.py. Document rate limiting policies, error response formats, and versioning strategy (if applicable). Explain how API endpoints integrate with frontend templates and JavaScript components. Address security considerations for each endpoint (CSRF protection, input validation). Provide client implementation guidelines and debugging tips using curl or Postman. Highlight endpoints critical for third-party integrations or automation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Models & ORM
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for the SQLAlchemy ORM implementation. Detail each model class (User, Company, PortfolioItem, Transaction, Dividend, Broker) including attributes, data types, relationships, and methods. Explain ORM mapping to database tables, relationship loading strategies (eager/lazy), and query optimization techniques. Document model validation logic, custom methods (e.g., portfolio valuation calculations), and event hooks. Use test_database_models.py to illustrate expected behavior and edge cases. Include code examples showing common queries (e.g., getting user portfolio, calculating returns). Address performance considerations like N+1 query prevention and indexing. Explain how models enforce business rules and maintain data integrity across transactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Business Logic Layer
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the business logic layer of the application. Detail the prediction pipeline workflow from user input to forecast visualization, including data retrieval (yfinance), preprocessing, model execution, and result aggregation. Explain trading operations logic: buy/sell order processing, commission calculations, wallet updates, and dividend recording. Document portfolio valuation algorithms and performance metric calculations. Use test_prediction_pipeline.py to illustrate expected behavior and edge cases. Include state management patterns for user sessions and transaction atomicity. Address error handling within business workflows and data consistency requirements. Provide examples of complex operations like batch predictions or portfolio rebalancing simulations.

wiki_catalogs.name: External Integrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on external integrations in the intelligent-stock-prediction system. Detail each integration: yfinance (historical data retrieval), Alpha Vantage (financial data and news), EODHD API (pre-calculated sentiment), Google News RSS (fallback source), and Finviz (primary news source). For each, document authentication methods, API endpoints used, rate limits, error handling strategies, and data transformation logic. Explain the fallback pattern implementation across sentiment sources and priority configurations. Include code examples showing API call patterns and response parsing. Address reliability considerations, timeout handling, and caching strategies. Document configuration options for API keys and endpoint customization. Highlight integration-specific troubleshooting steps and monitoring approaches.

wiki_catalogs.name: Error Handling & Monitoring
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on error handling and monitoring systems. Document exception handling strategies across the application stack (route-level, service-level, database operations). Explain logging configuration, log levels, and monitoring dashboard implementation. Detail error recovery mechanisms, particularly in sentiment analysis fallbacks and prediction pipeline failures. Use the ERROR_HANDLING_MONITORING.md guide to explain alerting systems and error classification. Include demonstrations from error_handling_monitoring_demo.py showing error simulation and recovery workflows. Address user-facing error messages versus developer logs. Document monitoring metrics tracked (API response times, prediction accuracy, system uptime) and visualization methods. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common failure scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Security Considerations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on security in the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Document authentication mechanisms (user registration, login/logout, session management), password hashing with secure algorithms, and role-based access control implementation. Explain CSRF protection on forms, input validation strategies, and SQL injection prevention through parameterized queries. Detail security testing approaches from test_e2e_api_perf_security_deployment.py including penetration testing scenarios. Address API security (key management, endpoint protection), data privacy considerations, and secure deployment practices. Include security headers implementation in Flask and protection against common web vulnerabilities (XSS, CSRF, insecure direct object references). Provide hardening guidelines for production deployment.

wiki_catalogs.name: Testing Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the testing strategy of the intelligent-stock-prediction system. Document the multi-layered testing approach: unit tests (individual functions), integration tests (component interactions), end-to-end tests (user workflows), performance tests, and security tests. Explain test organization in the tests/ directory and framework configuration (pytest.ini). Use COMPREHENSIVE_TESTING_FRAMEWORK.md to detail testing methodologies and coverage goals. Describe test data management, mocking strategies for external APIs, and CI/CD integration. Include guidance on writing new tests, running test suites (run_all_tests.py), and interpreting results. Address testing challenges specific to ML components (model stability, data drift) and financial calculations (precision, rounding). Provide metrics for test coverage and quality gates.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment & Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on deployment and production configuration of the intelligent-stock-prediction application. Document environment setup for production (Gunicorn, Nginx), configuration file management, and environment variable usage. Explain scaling considerations for handling multiple users and frequent prediction requests. Detail CI/CD integration possibilities, containerization options (Docker), and cloud deployment patterns. Use COMPLETE_INTEGRATION_SUMMARY.md to outline integration requirements and deployment topology. Address performance optimization for ML models in production, caching strategies, and database connection pooling. Include monitoring and logging setup for production environments, backup procedures, and disaster recovery plans. Provide checklists for production readiness and security audits.

wiki_catalogs.name: Developer Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on development practices for the intelligent-stock-prediction project. Document contribution guidelines from CONTRIBUTING.md including branching strategies, pull request workflows, and code review processes. Explain the code of conduct and community standards. Provide setup instructions for the development environment, debugging tools (IDE configuration, logging), and testing workflows. Detail coding standards, naming conventions, and documentation requirements. Include tips for working with ML components, frontend assets, and database migrations. Address common development challenges and onboarding steps for new contributors. Provide guidance on extending features, adding new prediction models, or integrating additional data sources while maintaining code quality.

wiki_catalogs.name: Advanced Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on advanced features of the intelligent-stock-prediction system. Detail use case configurations (HFT, retail, academic, fintech) and how they affect system behavior. Explain selectable sentiment sources and configuration-driven adaptation of analysis pipelines. Document performance optimization techniques including caching mechanisms, asynchronous processing, and model quantization. Use ADVANCED_FEATURES.md to describe sophisticated capabilities and advanced_features_demo.py to illustrate implementation patterns. Address customization options for expert users, such as tuning prediction models or configuring custom commission structures. Include guidance on extending the system with new ML algorithms or data sources. Highlight enterprise-grade features suitable for professional deployment.

wiki_catalogs.name: Demos & Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on demonstration scripts and usage examples. Provide detailed walkthroughs of each demo script: advanced_features_demo.py (showcasing configuration options), api_keys_demo.py (illustrating API integration setup), error_handling_monitoring_demo.py (demonstrating fault tolerance), selectable_sentiment_sources_demo.py (showing source selection logic), and use_case_sentiment_demo.py (highlighting use case adaptations). For each demo, explain the purpose, execution steps, expected outcomes, and educational value. Include annotated code excerpts and suggestions for modifying demos to test custom scenarios. Document how these demos serve as learning tools for new developers and validation tools for system capabilities. Address common issues encountered when running demos and troubleshooting tips.

wiki_catalogs.name: Project Management & Status
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on project management artifacts and development status. Document the project roadmap from project_roadmap.md, including milestones, release plans, and feature backlog. Explain implementation status tracking and progress metrics from implementation_status.md. Describe the kanban board workflow and task management methodology. Include historical context from project plan documents and evolution of development priorities. Address how status reports inform development decisions and stakeholder communication. Provide guidance on interpreting project management artifacts for new contributors. Highlight current focus areas, upcoming features, and deprecated components. Use these documents to illustrate agile practices within the project.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Intelligent Stock Prediction System

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
The Intelligent Stock Prediction System is a comprehensive financial application that combines machine learning models with advanced sentiment analysis to provide stock price predictions and investment recommendations. The system integrates multiple data sources and analytical approaches to deliver actionable insights for investors.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Provide accurate stock price predictions using multiple ML models (ARIMA, LSTM, Linear Regression)
- Analyze market sentiment from diverse news and social media sources
- Offer a complete trading simulation environment with portfolio management
- Support different user roles with admin capabilities for system monitoring
- Implement robust security features including CSRF protection and password hashing

### Target Audience
- Individual investors seeking data-driven investment recommendations
- Financial analysts requiring comprehensive market analysis tools
- Trading platform developers looking for reference implementations
- Academic researchers studying sentiment analysis in financial markets

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The application follows a full-stack architecture with distinct layers for data processing, business logic, and presentation:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client Browser] --> B[Flask Web Server]
    B --> C[ML Prediction Engine]
    B --> D[Sentiment Analysis Module]
    B --> E[Database Layer]
    C --> F[ARIMA Model]
    C --> G[LSTM Model]
    C --> H[Linear Regression]
    D --> I[Finviz Scraper]
    D --> J[API Integrations]
    D --> K[Google News RSS]
    E --> L[SQLite Database]
```

### Design Patterns
The system implements several key design patterns:
- **Model-View-Controller (MVC)**: Flask routes handle controller logic, templates serve as views, and database models represent the data layer
- **Dependency Injection**: API keys and configuration parameters are passed to components rather than hardcoded
- **Fallback Pattern**: Multiple sentiment sources with priority-based fallback mechanisms
- **Use Case Pattern**: Different configurations for various trading scenarios (HFT, retail, academic)

### System Relationships
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Frontend] -->|HTTP Requests| B[Flask App]
    B -->|Data Storage| C[SQLAlchemy]
    C --> D[SQLite Database]
    B -->|Price Data| E[yfinance]
    B -->|Prediction Models| F[ML Algorithms]
    B -->|Sentiment Analysis| G[news_sentiment.py]
    G --> H[Finviz]
    G --> I[EODHD API]
    G --> J[Alpha Vantage]
    G --> K[Google News]
    F --> L[ARIMA]
    F --> M[LSTM]
    F --> N[Linear Regression]
```

### Data Flow Diagram
```mermaid
flowchart LR
    A[User Input] --> B[Stock Symbol]
    B --> C{Data Retrieval}
    C --> D[yfinance Historical Data]
    C --> E[News Sources]
    D --> F[ML Models]
    E --> G[Sentiment Analysis]
    F --> H[Predictions]
    G --> I[Sentiment Score]
    H --> J[Recommendation Engine]
    I --> J
    J --> K[Investment Recommendation]
    K --> L[Web Interface]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- **main.py**: Primary application entry point with Flask routes and ML integration
- **news_sentiment.py**: Comprehensive sentiment analysis module with multiple source integrations

### Core Modules
- **Prediction Engine**: Implements ARIMA, LSTM, and Linear Regression models for price forecasting
- **Sentiment Analyzer**: Aggregates news and social media sentiment from multiple sources
- **Portfolio Manager**: Tracks user investments, transactions, and performance metrics
- **Authentication System**: User registration, login, and role-based access control

### Configuration Approach
- Environment variables for sensitive data (SECRET_KEY, DATABASE_URL)
- Configuration settings in Flask app object
- API keys passed as parameters to sentiment analyzer
- Use case-based configurations for different trading scenarios

### External Dependencies
- **requirements.txt**: Specifies core dependencies including TensorFlow, Keras, Flask, and financial data libraries
- **requirements_test.txt**: Testing dependencies including pytest and mocking libraries

### Integration Points
- **yfinance**: Retrieves historical stock price data
- **Alpha Vantage**: Alternative data source and news sentiment API
- **EODHD API**: Pre-calculated sentiment data and news
- **Finviz**: Primary news source with financial headlines
- **Google News RSS**: Fallback news source

### Component Relationships
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[main.py] --> B[news_sentiment.py]
    A --> C[yfinance]
    A --> D[Alpha Vantage]
    A --> E[SQLAlchemy]
    B --> F[Finviz]
    B --> G[EODHD API]
    B --> H[Alpha Vantage News]
    B --> I[Google News]
    A --> J[ARIMA]
    A --> K[LSTM]
    A --> L[Linear Regression]
    E --> M[SQLite]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The system provides a comprehensive suite of features for stock analysis and trading simulation:

1. **Multi-Model Price Prediction**: Combines ARIMA, LSTM, and Linear Regression models
2. **Advanced Sentiment Analysis**: Integrates multiple news and social media sources
3. **Portfolio Management**: Tracks investments, transactions, and performance
4. **Trading Simulation**: Buy/sell operations with commission calculations
5. **Admin Dashboard**: System monitoring and management capabilities
6. **User Authentication**: Secure login with role-based access control

### Implementation Highlights
- **Hybrid Sentiment Analysis**: Combines multiple sources with fallback mechanisms
- **Use Case Configurations**: Different settings for HFT, retail, academic, and other scenarios
- **Robust Error Handling**: Comprehensive exception handling and monitoring
- **Caching Mechanisms**: Optional Redis caching for improved performance
- **Batch Processing**: Efficient processing of multiple symbols for backtesting

### Feature Architecture
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> StockSelection: User selects stock
    StockSelection --> DataRetrieval: Fetch historical data
    DataRetrieval --> Prediction: Apply ML models
    DataRetrieval --> Sentiment: Analyze news sentiment
    Prediction --> Recommendation: Combine with sentiment
    Sentiment --> Recommendation
    Recommendation --> DisplayResults: Show predictions and advice
    DisplayResults --> Idle: Ready for next query
    Admin --> MonitorSystem: View analytics and metrics
    User --> ManagePortfolio: Buy/sell stocks
    ManagePortfolio --> UpdateDatabase: Record transactions
```

### Sentiment Analysis Architecture
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Sentiment Request] --> B{Use Case}
    B -->|HFT| C[Finviz + FinVADER]
    B -->|Retail| D[Tradestie + FinVADER]
    B -->|Quant| E[Alpha Vantage + FinVADER]
    B -->|Academic| F[Google News + FinVADER]
    B -->|Fintech| G[StockGeist + FinVADER]
    C --> H[Fast Processing]
    D --> I[Cost-Effective]
    E --> J[High Accuracy]
    F --> K[Historical Data]
    G --> L[Real-time Streams]
```

### Prediction Model Comparison
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Input Data] --> B[ARIMA]
    A --> C[LSTM]
    A --> D[Linear Regression]
    B --> E[Time Series Patterns]
    C --> F[Sequential Dependencies]
    D --> G[Linear Trends]
    E --> H[Predictions]
    F --> H
    G --> H
    H --> I[Ensemble Recommendation]
```

Sources:
- [main.py](/home/shlloh/intelligent-stock-prediction/main.py)
- [news_sentiment.py](/home/shlloh/intelligent-stock-prediction/news_sentiment.py)
- [requirements.txt](/home/shlloh/intelligent-stock-prediction/requirements.txt)
- [test_web_routes.py](/home/shlloh/intelligent-stock-prediction/tests/test_web_routes.py)
- [test_sentiment_sources.py](/home/shlloh/intelligent-stock-prediction/tests/test_sentiment_sources.py)
</blog>
